3.40 
Annulment of a marriage for failure to express a true intention 
1. A marriage may be annulled on the basis of an action brought by a spouse if he or she proves that he or she was unable to understand the meaning of his or her actions and to control them at the time of the celebration of the marriage. 
2. A spouse may claim annulment if he or she entered into the marriage under the influence of threat, duress or deceit. 
3. A spouse who has consented to the marriage because of a fundamental error may seek a declaration that the marriage is void. An error is fundamental if it is due to circumstances concerning the other spouse of which the spouse would not have consented to the marriage had he or she known. An error shall be presumed to be fundamental if the error is due to: 
1) a medical condition or sexual abnormality of the other spouse which makes normal family life impossible; 
2) the fact that the other spouse has committed a serious crime.
